Analysis : • The logo uses a combination of a distinctive maroon icon and a traditional serif font to convey professionalism and trustworthiness, likely targeting an audience in research, consulting, or academia. FINANCIAL SONAR™: REALITY RADAR ON COMPANY PERFORMANCE NASDAQGS AMD ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES INC. REGION NORTH AMERICA INDUSTRY SEMICONDUCTORS AND SEMICONDUCTOR EQUIPMENT OVERALL RATING FOR 1ST QUARTER 2025 SELL OUR EVALUATION OF AMD Advanced Micro Devices Inc. is showing strong Balance Sheet Quality and Cash Flow Quality, but Valuation suggests a higher amount of price risk, and Operating Efficiency and Earnings Quality are both weak. When combined, AMD deserves a SELL rating. The primary reason the overall rating dropped during the last quarter was a decrease in the Cash Flow rating. Another important factor in the downgraded overall rating was a declining Operating Efficiency rating due to weakening returns. Summary : This figure presents a "Financial Sonar" analysis for AMD for the 1st quarter of 2025, visually summarizing the company's financial strengths and weaknesses across five key dimensions. radial chart: Title & Dimensions : • Title: "FINANCIAL SONAR™ FOR AMD 1ST QUARTER 2025". • Five labeled segments: VALUATION, EARNINGS QUALITY, CASH FLOW QUALITY, OPERATING EFFICIENCY, BALANCE SHEET. Segment Ratings : • VALUATION: Labeled "MOST RISK", colored dark red, indicating highest risk. • EARNINGS QUALITY: Labeled "WEAKEST", colored red, indicating weakest area. • CASH FLOW QUALITY: Labeled "STRONG", colored blue, indicating strength. • OPERATING EFFICIENCY: Labeled "WEAK", colored yellow, indicating weakness. • BALANCE SHEET: Labeled "STRONGEST", colored green, indicating strongest area. Design Encodings : • Each segment uses a distinct color: dark red (valuation), red (earnings quality), blue (cash flow quality), yellow (operating efficiency), green (balance sheet). • Central labels ("MOST RISK", "WEAKEST", "STRONG", "WEAK", "STRONGEST") indicate the relative status of each dimension. • Radial layout with each segment occupying an equal wedge of the circle. Analysis : • AMD's financial profile for Q1 2025 is strongest in "BALANCE SHEET" and "CASH FLOW QUALITY". • The greatest risks and weaknesses are in "VALUATION" and "EARNINGS QUALITY". • "OPERATING EFFICIENCY" is also identified as weak, but not the weakest. • The chart visually emphasizes areas of risk (red hues) versus strength (green/blue hues), providing a quick comparative overview of financial health across dimensions. Summary : This figure shows the weekly stock price performance and trading volume for an unspecified security from July 2024 to June 2025, highlighting the 52-week high and low points. line chart: # Title & Axes : • No explicit title shown; content is a stock price and volume chart. • X-axis: Time, labeled by month from July 2024 to June 2025. • Y-axis (left): Stock price, range 75 to 200 (units not specified, likely USD). • Y-axis (right): Stock price, mirrored scale 75 to 200. • Secondary Y-axis (bottom): Average Weekly Volume, range 0 to 250 Million. # Data Points : • Stock price (line plot, shaded area under curve): – 52 Week High: 170.90 on 09/30/24 (marked with green dot). – 52 Week Low: 85.76 on 03/31/25 (marked with red dot). – General price movement: • July 2024: ~145 • Peaks at 170.90 in late September 2024 • Declines through late 2024 and early 2025 • Bottoms at 85.76 in late March 2025 • Recovers to ~145 by June 2025 • Average Weekly Volume (bar plot): – Bars for each week, values up to 250 Million – No specific numeric values for individual bars, but volume appears variable with some spikes. # Design Encodings : • Stock price: solid blue line with blue shaded area beneath. • 52-week high: green dot and annotation. • 52-week low: red dot and annotation. • Volume: gray bars below main chart. • Dual Y-axes for price, one for volume. • Annotations for high/low with exact values and dates. # Distribution & Trends : • Stock price rises from July to late September 2024, reaching a high. • Declines steadily through late 2024 and Q1 2025. • Hits a low at end of March 2025. • Recovers through Q2 2025, approaching previous levels by June. • Volume fluctuates, with some higher spikes but no clear trend. # Analysis : • The stock experienced a significant decline from its 52-week high (170.90) in late September 2024 to its 52-week low (85.76) at the end of March 2025, nearly halving in value. • After the low, the price rebounded strongly, recovering much of the lost ground by June 2025. • Volume shows periodic spikes but does not correlate directly with price peaks or troughs in the visible data. • The chart highlights a V-shaped recovery pattern after a prolonged decline. © 2025 Jefferson Research & Management Report prepared on **July 11, 2025** **Page 1 of 11** www.jeffersonresearch.com logo: Jefferson Research • The image is a logo featuring the company name "Jefferson Research" in a serif font, with a stylized red emblem consisting of three diagonal marks to the left of the text. • The text is rendered in a dark blue color, while the emblem is in a dark red. • The logo is horizontally oriented, with the emblem and text aligned on the same baseline. • No additional taglines, slogans, or graphical elements are present. Analysis : • The logo uses a classic serif font and a simple, bold emblem to convey professionalism and reliability, suitable for a research-focused organization. FINANCIAL SONAR™: REALITY RADAR ON COMPANY PERFORMANCE NASDAQGS AMD REGION NORTH AMERICA INDUSTRY SEMICONDUCTORS AND SEMICONDUCTOR EQUIPMENT ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES INC. ____________________________________ OVERALL RATING FOR 1ST QUARTER 2025 SELL EARNINGS QUALITY: WEAKEST Earnings quality has long been analyzed and used by investors as a measure of the fundamental quality of the company and its future prospects. Companies may be including certain items that increase reported earnings and often the amount of cash flow supporting the earnings may be weak. Jefferson adjusts for these kinds of items and other anomalies to produce an adjusted earnings number that more accurately reflects ongoing business fundamentals at Advanced Micro Devices Inc.. Reported earnings are compared to the Jefferson adjusted earnings as a means to gauge earnings quality. Also measured is the amount of cash flow that underpins earnings. The earnings quality for AMD remains WEAKEST. Though the reported net income increased during the last quarter to 709.0M from 482.0M, the quality of that reported net income declined. In addition, operating cash flow decreased during the last quarter to 939.0M from 1,299M, and the ratio of operating cash flow to earnings has also declined. Though both Earnings Quality measures declined, the rating for AMD is already a WEAKEST, the worst possible rating. Summary : This bar chart compares net income and adjusted net income (in millions) across several fiscal periods, showing both absolute values and the percentage of adjusted net income relative to net income. bar chart: Title & Axes : • Title: "NET INCOME VS. ADJUSTED NET INCOME" • Y-axis: Value in millions (0 to 3,000, with gridlines at 1,000 and 2,000) • X-axis: Time periods—Fiscal Year 2023, Fiscal Year 2024, Trailing 12 Months, Q4 2024, Q1 2025 Data Points : • Fiscal Year 2023: Net Income = 854.0, Adjusted Net Income = 641.0 (75.1%) • Fiscal Year 2024: Net Income = 1,641.0, Adjusted Net Income = 1,467.3 (89.4%) • Trailing 12 Months: Net Income = 2,227.0, Adjusted Net Income = 2,064.9 (92.7%) • Q4 2024: Net Income = 482.0, Adjusted Net Income = 455.8 (94.6%) • Q1 2025: Net Income = 709.0, Adjusted Net Income = 669.8 (94.5%) Design Encodings : • Net income shown as solid blue bars. • Adjusted net income shown as gray bars with a red triangle and value label. • Adjusted net income as a percentage of net income is listed above each period. • All values are in millions. Distribution & Trends : • Both net income and adjusted net income increase from Fiscal Year 2023 to the Trailing 12 Months. • The gap between net income and adjusted net income narrows over time, as shown by the increasing percentage. • Quarterly data (Q4 2024, Q1 2025) show higher percentages (over 94%) compared to earlier periods. Analysis : • Adjusted net income consistently trails net income but the difference decreases over time. • The proportion of adjusted net income to net income rises from 75.1% in Fiscal Year 2023 to over 94% in the most recent quarters, indicating a convergence between the two measures. • The largest absolute values are seen in the Trailing 12 Months period, while the highest adjusted/net income ratios are in the most recent quarters. Summary : This bar chart compares earnings and reported operating cash flow (in millions) across different time periods, showing operating cash flow as a percentage of earnings. bar chart: # Title & Axes : • Title: "EARNINGS VS. OPERATING CASH FLOW" • Y-axis: Value in millions (0 to 4,000, tick at 4,000) • X-axis: Time periods — Fiscal Year 2023, Fiscal Year 2024, Trailing 12 Months, Q4 2024, Q1 2025 # Data Points : • Fiscal Year 2023: Earnings = 854.0, Reported Operating Cash Flow = 1,667.0, Percentage = 195.2% • Fiscal Year 2024: Earnings = 1,641.0, Reported Operating Cash Flow = 3,041.0, Percentage = 185.3% • Trailing 12 Months: Earnings = 2,227.0, Reported Operating Cash Flow = 3,459.0, Percentage = 155.3% • Q4 2024: Earnings = 482.0, Reported Operating Cash Flow = 1,299.0, Percentage = 269.5% • Q1 2025: Earnings = 709.0, Reported Operating Cash Flow = 939.0, Percentage = 132.4% # Design Encodings : • Earnings shown as dark bars; Reported Operating Cash Flow as lighter bars with a red triangle symbol (Δ) above. • Percentages of operating cash flow to earnings are listed above each group. • All values are labeled directly on the bars. # Distribution & Trends : • Both earnings and operating cash flow are highest in the "Trailing 12 Months" period. • The ratio of operating cash flow to earnings is highest in Q4 2024 (269.5%) and lowest in Q1 2025 (132.4%). # Analysis : • Operating cash flow consistently exceeds earnings in all periods. • The ratio of operating cash flow to earnings fluctuates, peaking in Q4 2024 and dropping in Q1 2025. • There is a general trend of increasing earnings and operating cash flow from Fiscal Year 2023 to the "Trailing 12 Months," followed by a decrease in Q1 2025. • The visual emphasis on the red triangle (Δ) highlights reported operating cash flow values. % OF SALES Summary : This bar chart compares actual accruals and forecasted accruals as a percentage of sales across quarterly periods from Q2 2023 to Q1 2025. bar chart: Title & Axes : • Title: "ACCRUALS" • Y-axis: "% OF SALES" (range: 0.0% to 60.0%, tick marks at 0.0%, 20.0%, 40.0%, 60.0%) • X-axis: Quarterly periods from Q2 2023 to Q1 2025 (Q2 2023, Q3 2023, Q4 2023, Q1 2024, Q2 2024, Q3 2024, Q4 2024, Q1 2025) Data Points : • Actual Accruals (dark blue bars): – Q2 2023: 46.7% – Q3 2023: 49.3% – Q4 2023: 42.9% – Q1 2024: 42.5% – Q2 2024: 46.1% – Q3 2024: 51.9% – Q4 2024: 53.5% – Q1 2025: 51.5% • Forecasted Accruals (light pink bars): – Q2 2023: 40.1% – Q3 2023: 44.2% – Q4 2023: 47.7% – Q1 2024: 46.9% – Q2 2024: 46.6% – Q3 2024: 47.0% – Q4 2024: 49.8% – Q1 2025: 50.9% Design Encodings : • Actual Accruals: dark blue bars • Forecasted Accruals: light pink bars • Bars are grouped by quarter, with actual and forecasted values side by side • Data labels (percentages) are shown on each bar Distribution & Trends : • Both actual and forecasted accruals fluctuate between approximately 40% and 54% of sales. • Actual accruals are higher than forecasted in most quarters except Q4 2023 and Q1 2024. • Both series show an overall upward trend from Q2 2023 to Q1 2025. Analysis : • Actual accruals generally exceed forecasted accruals, especially in Q2 2023, Q3 2023, Q3 2024, Q4 2024, and Q1 2025. • The largest positive difference between actual and forecasted accruals occurs in Q4 2024 (actual: 53.5%, forecasted: 49.8%). • In Q4 2023 and Q1 2024, actual accruals fall below forecasted values. • Both actual and forecasted accruals trend upward over the period, with actual accruals peaking in Q4 2024. © 2025 Jefferson Research & Management Report prepared on **July 11, 2025** Page 2 of 11 www.jeffersonresearch.com logo: Jefferson Research • The image displays the logo for "Jefferson Research". • The logo consists of three stylized maroon diagonal marks on the left, followed by the text "Jefferson Research" in a bold, serif, dark blue font. • The text is horizontally aligned with the logo mark. • No additional taglines, icons, or graphical elements are present. • The background is white, and the logo is presented in a horizontal layout. Analysis : • The maroon marks may represent the letter "J" or abstract research-related symbolism, while the serif font conveys professionalism and tradition. FINANCIAL SONAR™: REALITY RADAR ON COMPANY PERFORMANCE NASDAQQGS AMD ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES INC. REGION NORTH AMERICA INDUSTRY SEMICONDUCTORS AND SEMICONDUCTOR EQUIPMENT OVERALL RATING FOR 1ST QUARTER 2025 SELL CASH FLOW QUALITY: STRONG Cash flow is considered by many investors to be the ultimate measure of company performance and more reliable than reported earnings. The Jefferson measurement eliminates items that are not part of recurring cash flow or the result of actual operations for Advanced Micro Devices Inc.. These adjustments to cash flow provide a truer measure of cash flow and the resultant cash flow quality rating. The cash flow quality rating for AMD declined from STRONGEST to STRONG as all three cash flow quality measures weakened. The quarterly operating cash flow quality declined with a reported number of 939.0M and an adjusted number that was 74.9% of reported. In addition, the quarterly free cash flow quality weakened with a reported number of 727.0M and an adjusted number that was 67.5% of reported. Together these changes represent deterioration from the previous period when the ratio of reported to adjusted numbers was higher. Summary : This bar chart presents operating cash flow and adjusted operating cash flow (in millions) for a company across several periods, including Fiscal Year 2023, Fiscal Year 2024, Trailing 12 Months, Q4 2024, and Q1 2025. It also shows the adjusted operating cash flow as a percentage of operating cash flow for each period. bar chart: Title & Axes : • Title: "OPERATING CASH FLOW" • Y-axis: Cash flow in millions (0 to 4,000, tick at 4,000) • X-axis: Time periods (Fiscal Year 2023, Fiscal Year 2024, Trailing 12 Months, Q4 2024, Q1 2025) Data Points : • Fiscal Year 2023: Operating Cash Flow = 1,667.0; Adjusted Operating Cash Flow = 1,366.0 • Fiscal Year 2024: Operating Cash Flow = 3,041.0; Adjusted Operating Cash Flow = 2,720.0 • Trailing 12 Months: Operating Cash Flow = 3,459.0; Adjusted Operating Cash Flow = 3,250.0 • Q4 2024: Operating Cash Flow = 1,299.0; Adjusted Operating Cash Flow = 1,198.0 • Q1 2025: Operating Cash Flow = 939.0; Adjusted Operating Cash Flow = 703.0 • Adjusted Operating Cash Flow as a Percentage of Operating Cash Flow: – Fiscal Year 2023: 81.9% – Fiscal Year 2024: 89.4% – Trailing 12 Months: 94.0% – Q4 2024: 92.2% – Q1 2025: 74.9% Design Encodings : • Light gray bars for Operating Cash Flow, dark gray or blue bars for Adjusted Operating Cash Flow. • Red triangle symbol (Δ) indicates Adjusted Operating Cash Flow. • Values labeled directly on bars. • Percentages shown above each period. Distribution & Trends : • Both cash flow measures increase from Fiscal Year 2023 to Fiscal Year 2024 and peak in the Trailing 12 Months. • Both measures decrease in Q4 2024 and further in Q1 2025. • The percentage of adjusted to operating cash flow is highest in the Trailing 12 Months (94.0%) and lowest in Q1 2025 (74.9%). Analysis : • Operating and adjusted operating cash flows show a rising trend from Fiscal Year 2023 to the Trailing 12 Months, followed by a decline in Q4 2024 and Q1 2025. • The proportion of adjusted to operating cash flow is generally high but drops sharply in Q1 2025. • The largest absolute cash flow values occur in the Trailing 12 Months period. • The gap between operating and adjusted operating cash flow widens in Q1 2025, as indicated by the lower percentage. Summary : This bar chart presents Free Cash Flow and Adjusted Free Cash Flow (in millions) for a company across several time periods, along with the percentage of Adjusted Free Cash Flow relative to Free Cash Flow. bar chart: # Title & Axes : • Title: "FREE CASH FLOW" • Y-axis: "IN MILLIONS" (values from 0 to 3,000, ticked at 1,000 intervals) • X-axis: Time periods — Fiscal Year 2023, Fiscal Year 2024, Trailing 12 Months, Q4 2024, Q1 2025 # Data Points : • Fiscal Year 2023: – Free Cash Flow: 1,121.0 – Adjusted Free Cash Flow: 820.0 – Percentage: 73.1% • Fiscal Year 2024: – Free Cash Flow: 2,405.0 – Adjusted Free Cash Flow: 2,084.0 – Percentage: 86.7% • Trailing 12 Months: – Free Cash Flow: 2,753.0 – Adjusted Free Cash Flow: 2,544.0 – Percentage: 92.4% • Q4 2024: – Free Cash Flow: 1,091.0 – Adjusted Free Cash Flow: 690.0 – Percentage: 63.2% • Q1 2025: – Free Cash Flow: 727.0 – Adjusted Free Cash Flow: 491.0 – Percentage: 67.5% # Design Encodings : • Free Cash Flow shown as solid bars (dark color). • Adjusted Free Cash Flow shown as lighter bars with a red triangle marker at the top. • Percentages of Adjusted Free Cash Flow to Free Cash Flow are listed above each pair of bars. • All values are labeled directly on the bars. # Distribution & Trends : • Both Free Cash Flow and Adjusted Free Cash Flow increase from Fiscal Year 2023 to Trailing 12 Months, then decrease in Q4 2024 and Q1 2025. • The percentage of Adjusted Free Cash Flow to Free Cash Flow peaks at 92.4% (Trailing 12 Months) and is lowest at 63.2% (Q4 2024). # Analysis : • The company’s Free Cash Flow and Adjusted Free Cash Flow both show growth from Fiscal Year 2023 through the Trailing 12 Months, followed by a decline in the subsequent quarters. • The proportion of Adjusted Free Cash Flow to Free Cash Flow is highest in the Trailing 12 Months period, indicating minimal adjustments, but drops notably in Q4 2024 and Q1 2025, suggesting larger adjustments or nonrecurring items in those quarters. • The visual distinction between the two metrics is clear, with adjusted values consistently lower than reported Free Cash Flow. Summary : This line chart shows the trends in Cash Flow ROI and Adjusted Cash Flow ROI from Q2 2023 through Q1 2025, highlighting changes over time and the relationship between the two metrics. line chart: Title & Axes : • Title: "CASH FLOW ROI" • Y-axis: Percentage scale from 0.0% to 6.0% • X-axis: Quarterly periods from Q2 23 to Q1 25 (Q2 23, Q3 23, Q4 23, Q1 24, Q2 24, Q3 24, Q4 24, Q1 25) Data Points : • Series 1 (solid line): Cash Flow ROI • Series 2 (dashed line): Adjusted Cash Flow ROI • Both series start above 4.0% in Q2 23, decline to a low near 2.0% in Q1 24, then rise steadily to just below 6.0% by Q1 25. Design Encodings : • Cash Flow ROI: solid line • Adjusted Cash Flow ROI: red dashed line • Shaded background under the lines • No markers on data points Distribution & Trends : • Both series show a downward trend from Q2 23 to Q1 24, reaching their lowest point around Q1 24. • From Q1 24 onward, both series trend upward, peaking in Q1 25. • The Adjusted Cash Flow ROI is consistently below the Cash Flow ROI except at the start. Analysis : • The data reveal a U-shaped pattern for both metrics, with a decline in ROI through 2023, a trough in early 2024, and a strong recovery through the end of 2024 into Q1 2025. • The gap between Cash Flow ROI and Adjusted Cash Flow ROI narrows at the start and end of the period, but is wider in the middle quarters. Summary : This line chart shows the trend of the "Flow Ratio" metric over quarterly periods from Q2 2023 to Q1 2025. line chart: Title & Axes : • Title: "FLOW RATIO". • X-axis: Quarterly periods, labeled as Q2 23, Q3 23, Q4 23, Q1 24, Q2 24, Q3 24, Q4 24, Q1 25. • Y-axis: Flow Ratio (no explicit units), tick labels at 0.00, 1.00, 2.00, 3.00. Data Points : • Single series (no explicit legend) with approximate values: – Q2 23: ~1.1 – Q3 23: ~1.2 – Q4 23: ~1.4 – Q1 24: ~1.5 – Q2 24: ~1.9 – Q3 24: ~1.8 – Q4 24: ~1.8 – Q1 25: ~2.0 Design Encodings : • Solid dark line for the data series. • Area under the line is shaded in light blue. • Bold font for the final x-axis label "Q1 25". Distribution & Trends : • The flow ratio increases steadily from Q2 23 to Q2 24. • There is a slight dip or plateau from Q2 24 to Q4 24. • The ratio rises again in Q1 25. Analysis : • The flow ratio shows a general upward trend over the observed period, nearly doubling from Q2 23 to Q1 25. • The increase is most pronounced between Q1 24 and Q2 24. • There is a brief stabilization or minor decline in the second half of 2024 before the upward trend resumes in Q1 25. Summary : This line chart shows the trends in debt coverage and adjusted debt coverage from Q2 2023 through Q1 2025, highlighting changes over time and the relationship between the two series. line chart: Title & Axes : • Title: "DEBT COVERAGE" • X-axis: Quarters from Q2 2023 to Q1 2025 (labels: Q2 23, Q3 23, Q4 23, Q1 24, Q2 24, Q3 24, Q4 24, Q1 25) • Y-axis: Debt coverage values (no explicit units; tick labels at 0, 50, 100, 150) Data Points : • Debt Coverage (solid blue line): – Q2 23: just under 100 – Q3 23: around 60 – Q4 23: around 50 – Q1 24: around 55 – Q2 24: around 80 – Q3 24: around 90 – Q4 24: peak at about 130 – Q1 25: drops to about 70 • Adjusted Debt Coverage (dashed red line): – Q2 23: just under 100 (slightly above blue line) – Q3 23: around 50 – Q4 23: around 35 – Q1 24: around 30 – Q2 24: around 45 – Q3 24: around 70 – Q4 24: peak at about 110 – Q1 25: drops to about 70 Design Encodings : • Debt Coverage: solid blue line, area under the line shaded blue. • Adjusted Debt Coverage: dashed red line. • No markers on data points. • No log scales, dual axes, or error bars. Distribution & Trends : • Both series start high in Q2 23, decline to a low in Q1 24, then rise sharply to a peak in Q4 24, followed by a drop in Q1 25. • The gap between the two series is largest at the Q4 24 peak. • Both series converge at Q1 25. Analysis : • Debt coverage and adjusted debt coverage follow similar trends, with both declining from Q2 23 to Q1 24, then rising to a peak in Q4 24 before dropping sharply in Q1 25. • The adjusted debt coverage is consistently lower than the unadjusted, except at the start where they are nearly equal. • The largest difference between the two occurs at the Q4 24 peak, suggesting adjustments have a greater impact during periods of high coverage. © 2025 Jefferson Research & Management Report prepared on **July 11, 2025** **Page 3 of 11** www.jeffersonresearch.com logo: Jefferson Research • The image is a logo consisting of a stylized red emblem on the left, followed by the text "Jefferson Research" in a bold serif font. • The emblem comprises three diagonal red marks, each resembling a forward slash, arranged in a triangular cluster. • The text "Jefferson Research" is rendered in dark blue, with "Jefferson" and "Research" separated by a single space and both words capitalized. • The logo is horizontally oriented, with the emblem to the left of the text. • The background is white, and there are no taglines or additional graphic elements. Analysis : • The logo uses a combination of a distinctive red emblem and formal serif typography to convey a sense of professionalism and research focus. The colour contrast and simple layout enhance legibility and brand recognition. FINANCIAL SONAR™: REALITY RADAR ON COMPANY PERFORMANCE NASDAQGS AMD ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES INC. REGION NORTH AMERICA INDUSTRY SEMICONDUCTORS AND SEMICONDUCTOR EQUIPMENT OVERALL RATING FOR 1ST QUARTER 2025 SELL OPERATING EFFICIENCY: WEAK The ability of Advanced Micro Devices Inc. to earn a profit is in part the result of how rapidly it converts its collection of assets into revenues and the resulting earnings and cash flow margins available. Operating Efficiency is measured by a combination of factors including: return on invested capital (ROIC), gross margin, EBIT margin, asset turnover, equity turnover, and lastly Staff, General, and Administrative costs as a percentage of sales (SGA). The operating efficiency rating for AMD declined from STRONG to WEAK as the return on incremental investment capital, EBIT margin, SGA costs and gross margin deteriorated since the last quarter. In addition, the EBIT margin deteriorated from 13.8% to 10.8%. The lower EBIT margin indicates that AMD's pre-financing costs have increased. Summary : This line chart shows the quarterly gross margin percentage from Q2 2023 to Q1 2025, highlighting a recent decrease compared to the previous quarter. line chart: Title & Axes : • Title: "GROSS MARGIN" • Subtitle: "Change from previous quarter: DOWN" • X-axis: Quarters from Q2 23, Q3 23, Q4 23, Q1 24, Q2 24, Q3 24, Q4 24, to Q1 25. • Y-axis: Gross margin percentage, labeled at 48.0%, 50.0%, 52.0%, and 54.0%. Data Points : • Single series (gross margin % by quarter): – Q2 23: just below 49.0% – Q3 23: just above 51.0% – Q4 23: about 50.0% – Q1 24: about 51.0% – Q2 24: about 53.0% – Q3 24: about 54.0% – Q4 24: slightly above 54.0% – Q1 25: slightly below 54.0% Design Encodings : • Solid dark line for gross margin. • Area under the line shaded in light blue. • "DOWN" in red with a downward arrow to indicate the latest quarter's decrease. Distribution & Trends : • Initial increase from Q2 23 to Q3 23. • Dip in Q4 23, followed by a steady rise through Q4 24. • Peak in Q4 24, then a slight decline in Q1 25. Analysis : • Gross margin increased overall from Q2 23 to Q4 24, peaking above 54%. • The most recent data point (Q1 25) shows a slight decrease from the previous quarter, as indicated by the "DOWN" annotation. • The trend is generally upward with a minor dip at the end. Summary : This line chart shows the adjusted EBIT margin over time from Q2 2023 to Q1 2025, highlighting quarterly changes and indicating a recent downward trend. line chart: Title & Axes : • Title: "EBIT MARGIN" • Subtitle: "Adjusted EBIT Margin" • X-axis: Quarters from Q2 23 to Q1 25 (labels: Q2 23, Q3 23, Q4 23, Q1 24, Q2 24, Q3 24, Q4 24, Q1 25) • Y-axis: EBIT Margin (%) with tick marks at -5.0%, 0.0%, 5.0%, 10.0%, 15.0% Data Points : • Single series: Adjusted EBIT Margin (dotted line) • Q2 23: ~0% • Q3 23: ~4% • Q4 23: ~5% • Q1 24: ~0% • Q2 24: ~4% • Q3 24: ~10% • Q4 24: ~15% • Q1 25: ~11% Design Encodings : • Dotted line for "Adjusted EBIT Margin" • Area under the line shaded in blue • Annotation at top right: "Change from previous quarter: DOWN" in red with a downward arrow Distribution & Trends : • EBIT margin rises from Q2 23 to Q4 23, dips in Q1 24, then climbs sharply to a peak in Q4 24, followed by a decline in Q1 25. Analysis : • The EBIT margin shows cyclical movement with a notable dip in Q1 24, a strong upward trend peaking in Q4 24, and a recent decrease in Q1 25 as indicated by the "DOWN" annotation. Summary : This line chart shows the net margin and adjusted net margin for a company over seven quarters, from Q2 2023 to Q1 2025, with a note that the change from the previous quarter is up in Q1 2025. line chart: Title & Axes : • Title: "NET MARGIN" • X-axis: Quarters, labeled as Q2 23, Q3 23, Q4 23, Q1 24, Q2 24, Q3 24, Q4 24, Q1 25. • Y-axis: Percentage (%), with tick marks at -5.0%, 0.0%, 5.0%, 10.0%, 15.0%. Data Points : • Net Margin (solid line): Values rise from below 0% in Q2 23, peak above 10% in Q4 23, drop near 0% in Q1 24, rise again to above 10% in Q3 24, dip to around 6% in Q4 24, and increase to about 9% in Q1 25. • Adjusted Net Margin (dashed line): Closely tracks the net margin, slightly lower at each point, following the same pattern. REGION NORTH AMERICA INDUSTRY SEMICONDUCTORS AND SEMICONDUCTOR EQUIPMENT OVERALL RATING FOR 1ST QUARTER 2025 SELL DEFINITIONS Adjusted Net Income: Adjusted Net Income is a company’s reported net income less adjustments for one-time and non-operating items yielding a more realistic picture of a company’s ongoing earnings. Accruals – Forecasted and Actual: The comparison of forecasted and actual accruals identifies a discretionary build not attributable to a company’s sales growth, and could be a sign of poor earnings quality. For our purposes, the forecasted accrual component is an aggregate measurement of total accruals (short-term balance sheet accounts) that distinguishes between “normalized” and “extraordinary” accruals. The normalized accruals are based on historical relationships between sales and accruals and are dynamically adjusted over time to account for changes in the ratio between these two variables. Normally, short term accruals will grow as sales grow – i.e., the “normalized” measure. Discretionary accruals are the portion of accruals that are in excess of the base factor and therefore exceed the normal and are “extraordinary”. **Adjusted Operating Cash Flow:** Adjusted Operating Cash Flow is reported operating cash flow less adjustments for one-time and non-operating items yielding a more realistic picture of a company's ongoing cash flow from operations. **Adjusted Free Cash Flow:** Adjusted Free Cash Flow is reported operating cash flow less adjustments for one-time, non-operating items and capital expenditures. This provides a more realistic picture of a company’s ongoing cash generation from operations after capital investments. **Flow Ratio:** The Flow Ratio is a measurement of management’s effectiveness in managing its working capital to maximize the company’s cash flows. The measure is a ratio of a company’s non-cash current assets to its non-interest bearing short-term liabilities.– These non-cash assets include items such as accounts receivable (which are essentially interest-free loans to customers) and inventory (which is subject to obsolescence or spoilage). The non-interest bearing liabilities are essentially interest-free loans to the company. A lower ratio implies tighter cash management for a company as it has less cash tied up in non-cash current assets and is able to utilize interest free loans from suppliers. **Cash Flow Return on Investment:** Cash Flow ROI is a measure of a company's ability to generate operating cash flow from its invested capital. Many analysts consider this measure preferable to an earnings return measure such as ROE since cash flow is considered a more reliable measure. **Adjusted Cash Flow Return on Investment:** Adjusted Cash Flow ROI is a measure of the ability to generate operating cash flow from its investment in capital calculated using a company’s adjusted cash flow. **Debt Coverage:** Debt Coverage is a measure of a company’s ability to cover its debt obligations with cash flow it generated from continuing operations. **Adjusted Debt Coverage:** Adjusted Debt Coverage is a measure of a company’s ability to cover its debt obligations with cash flow it generated from continuing operations, calculated using a company’s adjusted cash flow. **Adjusted Return on Invested Capital:** Adjusted ROIC assesses a company's efficiency at allocating the capital to profitable investments using a company's adjusted net income (see above) yielding a measure of how well a company is using its capital to generate returns. **Adjusted EBIT Margin:** Adjusted EBIT Margin is a measure of a company’s earnings before interest and income taxes less adjustments for one-time and non-operating items divided by a company’s sales. **Adjusted Net Margin:** Adjusted Net Margin is a measure of a company's net income less adjustments for one-time and non-operating items divided by a company's sales. **Return on Incremental Invested Capital:** ROIIC measures the relationship between incremental investment and incremental net operating profit after tax. This provides a measure of the returns a company is earning on recent investments rather than all investments as measured by ROIC. **Cash Conversion Cycle:** The Cash Conversion Cycle measures the number of days working capital is tied up from the date of purchase of raw materials until the collection of cash from the sale of the product. **Debt to Tangible Equity**: Debt to Tangible Equity is a ratio of a company's debt to equity less adjustments for goodwill and other intangible assets yielding tangible equity. **Debt to Tangible Assets:** Debt to Tangible Assets is a ratio of a company's debt to total assets less adjustments for goodwill and other intangible assets. **Price/Adjusted Earnings:** Adjusted Price/Earnings is a relative valuation measure comparing a company’s share price to its adjusted net income. **Price/Adjusted Cash Flow:** Adjusted Price/Cash Flow is a relative valuation measure comparing a company’s share price to its adjusted cash flow. **Price/Adjusted Earnings Growth:** Adjusted Price/Earnings Growth is a relative valuation measure comparing a company’s share price to its growth in adjusted earnings. © 2025 Jefferson Research & Management Report prepared on **July 11, 2025** **Page 10 of 11** www.jeffersonresearch.com logo: Jefferson Research • The image displays the logo for "Jefferson Research". • The logo consists of a stylized red emblem on the left, resembling three diagonal lines or abstract "J" shapes, followed by the company name "Jefferson Research" in a bold, serif, dark blue font. • The emblem and text are horizontally aligned, with the emblem occupying approximately the height of the text. • There is no tagline or additional text present. • The background is white, and the overall design is clean and professional. Analysis : • The use of dark blue and red suggests a formal, trustworthy, and authoritative brand identity, suitable for a research-focused organization. The Financial Sonar rating is the result of a point scoring system derived from the five main criteria. The more negative the rating, the more likely the overall rating will be a Sell. More positive criteria will support an Overall Rating of Buy. Jefferson Research & Management has developed the Financial Sonar™ Rating System which is based upon five analytical criteria: Earnings Quality, Cash Flow, Operating Efficiency, Balance Sheet, and Valuation. The first four criteria are rated in one of four categories (best to worst): Strongest, Strong, Weak, Weakest. Valuation is also rated in one of four categories (best to worst): Least Risk, Low Risk, Medium Risk, Most Risk. OUR EVALUATION OF AMD
Advanced Micro Devices Inc. is showing strong Balance Sheet Quality and Cash Flow Quality, but Valuation suggests a higher amount of price risk, and Operating Efficiency and Earnings Quality are both weak. When combined, AMD deserves a SELL rating.

The primary reason the overall rating dropped during the last quarter was a decrease in the Cash Flow rating. Another important factor in the downgraded overall rating was a declining Operating Efficiency rating due to weakening returns.

ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES INC.
____________________________________
OVERALL RATING FOR 1ST QUARTER 2025 SELL

EARNINGS QUALITY: WEAKEST  
Earnings quality has long been analyzed and used by investors as a measure of the fundamental quality of the company and its future prospects. Companies may be including certain items that increase reported earnings and often the amount of cash flow supporting the earnings may be weak. Jefferson adjusts for these kinds of items and other anomalies to produce an adjusted earnings number that more accurately reflects ongoing business fundamentals at Advanced Micro Devices Inc.. Reported earnings are compared to the Jefferson adjusted earnings as a means to gauge earnings quality. Also measured is the amount of cash flow that underpins earnings.

The earnings quality for AMD remains WEAKEST.

Though the reported net income increased during the last quarter to 709.0M from 482.0M, the quality of that reported net income declined. In addition, operating cash flow decreased during the last quarter to 939.0M from 1,299M, and the ratio of operating cash flow to earnings has also declined. Though both Earnings Quality measures declined, the rating for AMD is already a WEAKEST, the worst possible rating.

CASH FLOW QUALITY: STRONG
Cash flow is considered by many investors to be the ultimate measure of company performance and more reliable than reported earnings. The Jefferson measurement eliminates items that are not part of recurring cash flow or the result of actual operations for Advanced Micro Devices Inc.. These adjustments to cash flow provide a truer measure of cash flow and the resultant cash flow quality rating.
The cash flow quality rating for AMD declined from STRONGEST to STRONG as all three cash flow quality measures weakened.

The quarterly operating cash flow quality declined with a reported number of 939.0M and an adjusted number that was 74.9% of reported. In addition, the quarterly free cash flow quality weakened with a reported number of 727.0M and an adjusted number that was 67.5% of reported. Together these changes represent deterioration from the previous period when the ratio of reported to adjusted numbers was higher.

OPERATING EFFICIENCY: WEAK  
The ability of Advanced Micro Devices Inc. to earn a profit is in part the result of how rapidly it converts its collection of assets into revenues and the resulting earnings and cash flow margins available. Operating Efficiency is measured by a combination of factors including: return on invested capital (ROIC), gross margin, EBIT margin, asset turnover, equity turnover, and lastly Staff, General, and Administrative costs as a percentage of sales (SGA).
The operating efficiency rating for AMD declined from STRONG to WEAK as the return on incremental investment capital, EBIT margin, SGA costs and gross margin deteriorated since the last quarter.
In addition, the EBIT margin deteriorated from 13.8% to 10.8%. The lower EBIT margin indicates that AMD's pre-financing costs have increased.

BALANCE SHEET QUALITY: STRONGEST
The balance sheet shows the ability of Advanced Micro Devices Inc. to pay its bills and fund future growth. It also provides clues to aggressive accounting since reported earnings that do not generate cash flow generally end up somewhere on the balance sheet. The following are analyzed in determining balance sheet quality: quick ratio, current ratio, cash position, accounts receivable days sales outstanding (AR DSOs), and number of days inventory is held prior to sale to customers (Inv Days).
The balance sheet rating for AMD strengthened from STRONG to STRONGEST as the  cash position, AR DSOs, current ratio, and quick ratio improved over the last quarter.

The cash position increased from 5,132M to 7,310M. With more cash on hand AMD will be better able to meet financial obligations. In addition, AR DSOs improved from 86 to 74 days, indicating that AMD has shortened the time it takes on average to receive payment from its customers, thereby increasing liquidity.

VALUATION: MOST RISK
An unfavorable valuation (a MEDIUM RISK or MOST RISK rating) implies higher potential downward price risk that is evidenced by a company price multiple that is higher than the corresponding sector average. The valuation rating is based on both absolute and relative levels at Advanced Micro Devices Inc. compared to its peers within its sector based on price to earnings (PE), price to earnings growth (PEG), price to sales (PS), and price to cash flow (PCF).

The valuation rating for AMD remains a MOST RISK as the price to cash flow, price to earnings, and PEG ratios became more attractive over the last quarter while the price to sales ratio became less attractive.

Even though AMD's PCF ratio relative to the sector average PCF improved from 6.22X to 4.47X during the last quarter, the decline in the PS ratio relative to the sector average PS offset this by deteriorating from 2.45X to 2.50X.

DEFINITIONS

Adjusted Net Income: Adjusted Net Income is a company’s reported net income less adjustments for one-time and non-operating items yielding a more realistic picture of a company’s ongoing earnings.

Accruals – Forecasted and Actual: The comparison of forecasted and actual accruals identifies a discretionary build not attributable to a company’s sales growth, and could be a sign of poor earnings quality. For our purposes, the forecasted accrual component is an aggregate measurement of total accruals (short-term balance sheet accounts) that distinguishes between “normalized” and “extraordinary” accruals. The normalized accruals are based on historical relationships between sales and accruals and are dynamically adjusted over time to account for changes in the ratio between these two variables. Normally, short term accruals will grow as sales grow – i.e., the “normalized” measure. Discretionary accruals are the portion of accruals that are in excess of the base factor and therefore exceed the normal and are “extraordinary”.

**Adjusted Operating Cash Flow:** Adjusted Operating Cash Flow is reported operating cash flow less adjustments for one-time and non-operating items yielding a more realistic picture of a company's ongoing cash flow from operations.

**Adjusted Free Cash Flow:** Adjusted Free Cash Flow is reported operating cash flow less adjustments for one-time, non-operating items and capital expenditures. This provides a more realistic picture of a company’s ongoing cash generation from operations after capital investments.

**Flow Ratio:** The Flow Ratio is a measurement of management’s effectiveness in managing its working capital to maximize the company’s cash flows. The measure is a ratio of a company’s non-cash current assets to its non-interest bearing short-term liabilities.– These non-cash assets include items such as accounts receivable (which are essentially interest-free loans to customers) and inventory (which is subject to obsolescence or spoilage). The non-interest bearing liabilities are essentially interest-free loans to the company. A lower ratio implies tighter cash management for a company as it has less cash tied up in non-cash current assets and is able to utilize interest free loans from suppliers.

**Cash Flow Return on Investment:** Cash Flow ROI is a measure of a company's ability to generate operating cash flow from its invested capital. Many analysts consider this measure preferable to an earnings return measure such as ROE since cash flow is considered a more reliable measure.

**Adjusted Cash Flow Return on Investment:** Adjusted Cash Flow ROI is a measure of the ability to generate operating cash flow from its investment in capital calculated using a company’s adjusted cash flow.
**Debt Coverage:** Debt Coverage is a measure of a company’s ability to cover its debt obligations with cash flow it generated
from continuing operations.

**Adjusted Debt Coverage:** Adjusted Debt Coverage is a measure of a company’s ability to cover its debt obligations with cash flow it generated from continuing operations, calculated using a company’s adjusted cash flow.

**Adjusted Return on Invested Capital:** Adjusted ROIC assesses a company's efficiency at allocating the capital to profitable investments using a company's adjusted net income (see above) yielding a measure of how well a company is using its capital to generate returns.

**Adjusted EBIT Margin:** Adjusted EBIT Margin is a measure of a company’s earnings before interest and income taxes less adjustments for one-time and non-operating items divided by a company’s sales.
**Adjusted Net Margin:** Adjusted Net Margin is a measure of a company's net income less adjustments for one-time and non-operating items divided by a company's sales.

**Return on Incremental Invested Capital:** ROIIC measures the relationship between incremental investment and incremental net operating profit after tax. This provides a measure of the returns a company is earning on recent investments rather than all investments as measured by ROIC.

**Cash Conversion Cycle:** The Cash Conversion Cycle measures the number of days working capital is tied up from the date of purchase of raw materials until the collection of cash from the sale of the product.
**Debt to Tangible Equity**: Debt to Tangible Equity is a ratio of a company's debt to equity less adjustments for goodwill and other intangible assets yielding tangible equity.
**Debt to Tangible Assets:** Debt to Tangible Assets is a ratio of a company's debt to total assets less adjustments for goodwill and other intangible assets.
**Price/Adjusted Earnings:** Adjusted Price/Earnings is a relative valuation measure comparing a company’s share price to its adjusted net income.
**Price/Adjusted Cash Flow:** Adjusted Price/Cash Flow is a relative valuation measure comparing a company’s share price to its adjusted cash flow.
**Price/Adjusted Earnings Growth:** Adjusted Price/Earnings Growth is a relative valuation measure comparing a company’s share price to its growth in adjusted earnings.

ABOUT THE FINANCIAL SONAR™ REPORT & METHODOLOGY

The Jefferson Financial Sonar™ ratings system classifies companies into three categories: Buy, Hold and Sell. The Financial Sonar rating is the result of a point scoring system derived from the five main criteria. The more negative the rating, the more likely the overall rating will be a Sell. More positive criteria will support an Overall Rating of Buy.

Jefferson Research & Management has developed the Financial Sonar™ Rating System which is based upon five analytical criteria: Earnings Quality, Cash Flow, Operating Efficiency, Balance Sheet, and Valuation. The first four criteria are rated in one of four categories (best to worst): Strongest, Strong, Weak, Weakest. Valuation is also rated in one of four categories (best to worst): Least Risk, Low Risk, Medium Risk, Most Risk.

ABOUT JEFFERSON RESEARCH & MANAGEMENT

Jefferson Research & Management is an independent investment research and advisory firm founded in 1989 and based in Portland, Oregon.  The firm has been providing fundamental research to institutional and individual clients for more than 20 years. Financial Sonar™ ratings are based on a proprietary rating system developed by Jefferson Research & Management that measures the changes in company fundamentals using information from financial statements.
